title: 106_s558
content: The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" is the short title of the Act. It also includes an amendment to Title 31. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" includes an amendment to Title 31, inserting a new section for continuing appropriations if regular appropriation bills are not passed before the fiscal year begins. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" includes provisions for continuing appropriations at a specified rate of operations if regular appropriation bills are not passed before the fiscal year begins. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" allows for continuing appropriations at a specified rate of operations if regular appropriation bills are not passed before the fiscal year begins. Appropriations and funds for a project or activity are available from the first day of a lapse in appropriations until the earlier of when the regular appropriation bill becomes law or the last day of the fiscal year. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" ensures that appropriations for projects or activities in a fiscal year are subject to previous terms and conditions. Funds cover all expenses incurred during the fiscal year, and expenditures are charged to the appropriate appropriation. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" ensures that appropriations for projects or activities in a fiscal year are subject to specific conditions. Regular appropriation bills cover various project categories and activities. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" categorizes projects and activities into different departments and agencies, such as Agriculture, Defense, Education, and Foreign Assistance, among others. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" categorizes projects and activities into different departments and agencies, including Military construction, Department of Transportation, Treasury Department, U.S. Postal Service, Executive Office of the President, certain independent agencies, and the legislative branch. A technical amendment is made to the analysis of chapter 13 of title 31, United States Code. The amendments made by the "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" apply to fiscal years starting from 2000 and expire after 2001. These changes do not affect government obligations under other laws, such as Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid.
